<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-United_Nations skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">United Nations</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
</p>
<div class="dablink">"UN" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/UN_(disambiguation)" title="UN (disambiguation)">UN (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Good_article&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Good article (page does not exist)">Template:Good article</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-indef</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_British_(Oxford)_English&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use British (Oxford) English (page does not exist)">Template:Use British (Oxford) English</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_geopolitical_organization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox geopolitical organization (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox geopolitical organization</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Contains_Chinese_text&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Contains Chinese text (page does not exist)">Template:Contains Chinese text</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Contains_Arabic_text&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Contains Arabic text (page does not exist)">Template:Contains Arabic text</a>
</p><p>The <b>United Nations</b> (<b>UN</b>) is an <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmental_organisation" title="Intergovernmental organisation" class="mw-redirect">intergovernmental organisation</a> established on 24 October 1945 to promote international cooperation. A replacement for the ineffective <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>, the organisation was created following <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> to prevent another such conflict. At its founding, the UN had 51&#160;<a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">member states</a>; there are now&#160;193. The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">UN Headquarters</a> resides in international territory in New York City, with further main offices in <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Office_at_Geneva&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Office at Geneva (page does not exist)">Geneva</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Office_at_Nairobi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Office at Nairobi (page does not exist)">Nairobi</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Office_at_Vienna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Office at Vienna (page does not exist)">Vienna</a>. The organisation is financed by assessed and voluntary contributions from its member states. Its objectives include maintaining international peace and security, promoting human rights, fostering social and economic development, protecting the environment, and providing humanitarian aid in cases of famine, natural disaster, and armed conflict.
</p><p>During World War II, US President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> initiated talks on a successor agency to the League of Nations, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" title="United Nations Charter">United Nations Charter</a> was drafted at <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Conference_on_International_Organization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Conference on International Organization (page does not exist)">a conference</a> in April–June 1945; this charter took effect on 24 October 1945, and the UN began operation. The UN's mission to preserve world peace was complicated in its early decades by the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> between the US and USSR and their respective allies, though the organization participated in major actions in <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_the_Congo" title="United Nations Operation in the Congo">the Congo</a>, as well as approving the creation of the state Israel in 1947. The organisation's membership grew significantly following widespread <a href="/wiki/Decolonization" title="Decolonization">decolonization</a> in the 1960s, and by the 1970s, its budget for economic and social development programmes far outstripped its spending on <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a>. After the end of the Cold War, the UN took on major military and peacekeeping missions in <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Kuwait</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Transition_Assistance_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Transition Assistance Group (page does not exist)">Namibia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Transitional_Authority_in_Cambodia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (page does not exist)">Cambodia</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Protection_Force" title="United Nations Protection Force">Bosnia</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Assistance_Mission_for_Rwanda" title="United Nations Assistance Mission for Rwanda">Rwanda</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_Somalia_II" title="United Nations Operation in Somalia II">Somalia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_in_Darfur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War in Darfur (page does not exist)">Sudan</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kivu_conflict&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kivu conflict (page does not exist)">the Democratic Republic of Congo</a> with varying degrees of success.
</p><p>The UN has six principal organs: the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">General Assembly</a> (the main deliberative assembly); the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a> (for deciding certain resolutions for peace and security); the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Economic_and_Social_Council" title="United Nations Economic and Social Council">Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC)</a> (for promoting international economic and social co-operation and development); the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Secretariat" title="United Nations Secretariat">Secretariat</a> (for providing studies, information, and facilities needed by the UN); the <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice" title="International Court of Justice">International Court of Justice</a> (the primary judicial organ); and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Trusteeship_Council" title="United Nations Trusteeship Council">United Nations Trusteeship Council</a> (inactive since 1994). <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_System" title="United Nations System">UN System</a> agencies include the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">World Bank Group</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO (page does not exist)">UNESCO</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNICEF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNICEF (page does not exist)">UNICEF</a>. The UN's most prominent officer is the <a href="/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations" title="Secretary-General of the United Nations">Secretary-General</a>, an office held by <a href="/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon" title="Ban Ki-moon">Ban Ki-moon</a> of South Korea since 2007. Non-governmental organisations may be granted consultative status with ECOSOC and other agencies to participate in the UN's work.
</p><p>The organisation won the 2001 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Peace_Prize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Peace Prize (page does not exist)">Nobel Peace Prize</a>, and a number of its officers and agencies have also been awarded the prize. Other evaluations of the UN's effectiveness have been mixed. Some commentators believe the organisation to be an important force for peace and human development, while others have called the organisation ineffective, corrupt, or biased.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chile_signs_UN_Charter_1945.jpg" title="File:Chile signs UN Charter 1945.jpg">File:Chile signs UN Charter 1945.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chilean</a> delegation signing the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" title="United Nations Charter">UN Charter</a> in San Francisco, 1945</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Background_and_creation">Background and creation</span></h3>
<p>In the century prior to the UN's creation, several international treaty organisations and conferences had been formed to regulate conflicts between nations, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Committee_of_the_Red_Cross&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Committee of the Red Cross (page does not exist)">International Committee of the Red Cross</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hague_Conventions_of_1899_and_1907" title="Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907">Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> Following the catastrophic loss of life in <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919" title="Paris Peace Conference, 1919">Paris Peace Conference</a> established the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> to maintain harmony between countries.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> This organisation resolved some territorial disputes and created international structures for areas such as postal mail, aviation, and opium control, some of which would later be absorbed into the UN.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> However, the League lacked representation for colonial peoples (then half the world's population) and significant participation from several major powers, including the US, USSR, Germany, and Japan; it failed to act against the 1931 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_invasion_of_Manchuria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese invasion of Manchuria (page does not exist)">Japanese invasion of Manchuria</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Italo-Ethiopian_War" title="Second Italo-Ethiopian War">Second Italo-Ethiopian War</a> in 1935, the 1937 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_invasion_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese invasion of China (page does not exist)">Japanese invasion of China</a>, and German expansions under <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a> that culminated in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest concrete plan for a new world organisation began under the aegis of the <a href="/wiki/US_State_Department" title="US State Department" class="mw-redirect">US State Department</a> in 1939. US President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> first coined the term 'United Nations' as a term to describe the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied countries</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> The term was first officially used on 1&#160;January 1942, when 26&#160;governments signed the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Charter" title="Atlantic Charter">Atlantic Charter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> On 25&#160;April 1945, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Conference_on_International_Organization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Conference on International Organization (page does not exist)">UN Conference on International Organization</a> began in San Francisco, attended by 50&#160;governments and a number of non-governmental organisations involved in drafting the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" title="United Nations Charter">United Nations Charter</a>. The UN officially came into existence on 24&#160;October 1945 upon ratification of the Charter by the five then-permanent members of the Security Council—France, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of China (1912–1949) (page does not exist)">Republic of China</a>, the Soviet Union, the UK and the US—and by a majority of the other 46 signatories.<sup id="cite_ref-unmilestones_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unmilestones-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first meetings of the General Assembly, with 51&#160;nations represented,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> and the Security Council took place in <a href="/wiki/Methodist_Central_Hall_Westminster" title="Methodist Central Hall Westminster">Methodist Central Hall Westminster</a> in London beginning 6 January 1946.<sup id="cite_ref-unmilestones_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unmilestones-6">[6]</a></sup> The General Assembly selected New York City as the site for <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a>, and the facility was completed in 1952. Its site—like UN headquarters buildings in <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nairobi" title="Nairobi">Nairobi</a>—is designated as <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_territory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International territory (page does not exist)">international territory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Norwegian Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Trygve_Lie" title="Trygve Lie">Trygve Lie</a> was elected as the first UN Secretary-General.<sup id="cite_ref-unmilestones_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unmilestones-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cold_War_era">Cold War era</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dag_Hammarskjold.jpg" title="File:Dag Hammarskjold.jpg">File:Dag Hammarskjold.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Dag_Hammarskj%C3%B6ld" title="Dag Hammarskjöld">Dag Hammarskjöld</a> was a particularly active Secretary-General from 1953 until his death in 1961.</div></div></div>
<p>Though the UN's primary mandate was <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a>, the division between the US and USSR often paralysed the organisation, generally allowing it to intervene only in conflicts distant from the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> (A notable exception was the 1950 Security Council resolution authorising a US-led coalition to repel the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">North Korean invasion of South Korea</a>, passed in the absence of the USSR.)<sup id="cite_ref-unmilestones_6-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unmilestones-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> In 1947, the General Assembly approved a resolution to partition <a href="/wiki/Palestine" title="Palestine">Palestine</a>, approving the creation of the state of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Israel (page does not exist)">Israel</a>. Two years later, UN official <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Bunche" title="Ralph Bunche">Ralph Bunche</a> negotiated an armistice to the resulting conflict.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> In 1956, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Emergency_Force" title="United Nations Emergency Force">first UN peacekeeping force</a> was established to end the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-unmilestones_6-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unmilestones-6">[6]</a></sup> however, the UN was unable to intervene against the USSR's simultaneous invasion of Hungary following <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1956" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1956">that country's revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1960, the UN deployed <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_the_Congo" title="United Nations Operation in the Congo">United Nations Operation in the Congo</a> (UNOC), the largest military force of its early decades, to bring order to the breakaway <a href="/w/index.php?title=State_of_Katanga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="State of Katanga (page does not exist)">State of Katanga</a>, restoring it to the control of the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo" title="Democratic Republic of the Congo">Democratic Republic of the Congo</a> by 1964.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> While travelling to meet with rebel leader <a href="/wiki/Moise_Tshombe" title="Moise Tshombe">Moise Tshombe</a> during the conflict, <a href="/wiki/Dag_Hammarskj%C3%B6ld" title="Dag Hammarskjöld">Dag Hammarskjöld</a>, often named as one of the UN's most effective Secretaries-General,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> died in a plane crash; months later he was posthumously awarded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Peace_Prize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Peace Prize (page does not exist)">Nobel Peace Prize</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> In 1964, Hammarskjöld's successor <a href="/wiki/U_Thant" title="U Thant">U Thant</a> deployed the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Peacekeeping_Force_in_Cyprus" title="United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus">United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus</a>, which would become one of the UN's longest-running peacekeeping missions.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the spread of <a href="/wiki/Decolonization" title="Decolonization">decolonization</a> in the 1960s, the organisation's membership saw an influx of newly independent nations. In 1960 alone, 17&#160;new states joined the UN, 16&#160;of them from Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-unmilestones_6-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unmilestones-6">[6]</a></sup> On 25&#160;October 1971, over US opposition but with the support of many <a href="/wiki/Third_World" title="Third World">Third World</a> nations, the mainland, communist <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">People's Republic of China</a> was given the Chinese seat on the Security Council in place of the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Republic of China</a> that occupied Taiwan; the vote was widely seen as a sign of waning US influence in the organisation.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> Third World nations organised into the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">Group of 77</a> coalition under the leadership of Algeria, which briefly became a dominant power at the UN.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> In 1975, a bloc of USSR and Third World nations passed <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_3379" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 3379">a resolution</a> over strenuous US and Israeli opposition declaring <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a> to be racism; the resolution was repealed in 1991, shortly after the end of the Cold War.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>With an increasing Third World presence and the failure of UN mediation in conflicts in the <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Middle East</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1965">Kashmir</a>, the UN increasingly shifted its attention to its ostensibly secondary goals of economic development and cultural exchange.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> By the 1970s, the UN budget for social and economic development was far greater than its peacekeeping budget.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Cold_War">Post-Cold War</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kofi_Annan.jpg" title="File:Kofi Annan.jpg">File:Kofi Annan.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Secretary-General <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">Kofi Annan</a> (1997–2006)</div></div></div>
<p>After the Cold War, the UN saw a radical expansion in its peacekeeping duties, taking on more missions in ten years than it had in the previous four decades.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> Between 1988 and 2000, the number of adopted Security Council resolutions more than doubled, and the peacekeeping budget increased more than tenfold.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> The UN negotiated an end to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Salvadoran_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Salvadoran Civil War (page does not exist)">Salvadoran Civil War</a>, launched a successful <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Transition_Assistance_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Transition Assistance Group (page does not exist)">peacekeeping mission in Namibia</a>, and oversaw democratic elections in post-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Apartheid_in_South_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Apartheid in South Africa (page does not exist)">apartheid</a> South Africa and post-<a href="/wiki/Khmer_Rouge" title="Khmer Rouge">Khmer Rouge</a> Cambodia.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> In 1991, the UN authorised a <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">US-led coalition</a> that repulsed the Iraqi <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Kuwait" title="Invasion of Kuwait">invasion of Kuwait</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Undersecretary-General <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brian_Urquhart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brian Urquhart (page does not exist)">Brian Urquhart</a> later described the hopes raised by these successes as a "false renaissance" for the organization, given the more troubled missions that followed.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>Though the UN Charter had been written primarily to prevent aggression by one nation against another, in the early 1990s, the UN faced a number of simultaneous, serious crises within nations such as Somalia, Haiti, Mozambique, and the former Yugoslavia.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_Somalia_II" title="United Nations Operation in Somalia II">UN mission in Somalia</a> was widely viewed as a failure after the US withdrawal following casualties in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mogadishu_(1993)" title="Battle of Mogadishu (1993)">Battle of Mogadishu</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Protection_Force" title="United Nations Protection Force">UN mission to Bosnia</a> faced "worldwide ridicule" for its indecisive and confused mission in the face of ethnic cleansing.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> In 1994, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Assistance_Mission_for_Rwanda" title="United Nations Assistance Mission for Rwanda">United Nations Assistance Mission for Rwanda</a> failed to intervene in the <a href="/wiki/Rwandan_Genocide" title="Rwandan Genocide">Rwandan Genocide</a> amid Security Council indecision.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beginning in last decades of the Cold War, American and European critics of the UN condemned the organisation for perceived mismanagement and corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> In 1984, US President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> withdrew his nation's funding from <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO (page does not exist)">UNESCO</a> (the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, founded 1946) over mismanagement allegations, followed by Britain and Singapore.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> Secretary-General <a href="/wiki/Boutros_Boutros-Ghali" title="Boutros Boutros-Ghali">Boutros Boutros-Ghali</a> (1992–96) initiated a reform of the Secretariat, downsising the organisation somewhat.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NST_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NST-33">[33]</a></sup> His successor, <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">Kofi Annan</a> (1997–2006), initiated further management reforms in the face of US threats to withhold its UN dues.<sup id="cite_ref-NST_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NST-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the late 1990s and 2000s, UN-authorised international interventions took a wider variety of forms. The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Mission_in_Sierra_Leone" title="United Nations Mission in Sierra Leone">UN mission</a> in the 1991–2002 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sierra_Leone_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sierra Leone Civil War (page does not exist)">Sierra Leone Civil War</a> was supplemented by British <a href="/wiki/Royal_Marines" title="Royal Marines">Royal Marines</a>, and the UN-authorised <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present) (page does not exist)">2001 invasion of Afghanistan</a> was overseen by <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> In 2003, the US <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraq_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraq War (page does not exist)">invaded Iraq</a> despite failing to pass a UN Security Council resolution for authorization, prompting a new round of questioning of the organisation's effectiveness.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Under the current Secretary-General, <a href="/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon" title="Ban Ki-moon">Ban Ki-moon</a>, the UN has intervened with peacekeepers in crises including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_in_Darfur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War in Darfur (page does not exist)">War in Darfur</a> in Sudan and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kivu_conflict&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kivu conflict (page does not exist)">Kivu conflict</a> in the Democratic Republic of Congo and sent observers and chemical weapons inspectors to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Syrian_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Syrian Civil War (page does not exist)">Syrian Civil War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> In 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Secretary-General%27s_Internal_Review_Panel_on_United_Nations_Action_in_Sri_Lanka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Secretary-General's Internal Review Panel on United Nations Action in Sri Lanka (page does not exist)">an internal review</a> of UN actions in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alleged_war_crimes_during_the_final_stages_of_the_Sri_Lankan_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alleged war crimes during the final stages of the Sri Lankan Civil War (page does not exist)">the final battles</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Civil_War" title="Sri Lankan Civil War">Sri Lankan Civil War</a> in 2009 concluded that the organisation had suffered "systemic failure".<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> One hundred and one UN personnel died in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Haiti_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Haiti earthquake (page does not exist)">2010 Haiti earthquake</a>, the worst loss of life in the organisation's history.<sup id="cite_ref-unmilestones_6-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unmilestones-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Structure">Structure</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The United Nations' system is based on five principal organs: the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">General Assembly</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Economic_and_Social_Council" title="United Nations Economic and Social Council">Economic and Social Council</a> (ECOSOC), the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Secretariat" title="United Nations Secretariat">Secretariat</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice" title="International Court of Justice">International Court of Justice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> A sixth principal organ, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Trusteeship_Council" title="United Nations Trusteeship Council">Trusteeship Council</a>, suspended operations in 1994, upon the independence of <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a>, the last remaining UN trustee territory.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Four of the five principal organs are located at the main UN Headquarters in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> The International Court of Justice is located in <a href="/wiki/The_Hague" title="The Hague">The Hague</a>, while other major agencies are based in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Office_at_Geneva&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Office at Geneva (page does not exist)">UN offices at Geneva</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Office_at_Vienna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Office at Vienna (page does not exist)">Vienna</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Office_at_Nairobi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Office at Nairobi (page does not exist)">Nairobi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Other UN institutions are located throughout the world. The six <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official languages</a> of the United Nations, used in intergovernmental meetings and documents, are Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian, and Spanish.<sup id="cite_ref-langs_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-langs-44">[44]</a></sup> On the basis of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Convention_on_the_Privileges_and_Immunities_of_the_United_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Convention on the Privileges and Immunities of the United Nations (page does not exist)">Convention on the Privileges and Immunities of the United Nations</a>, the UN and its agencies are <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_immunity" title="Diplomatic immunity">immune</a> from the laws of the countries where they operate, safeguarding the UN's impartiality with regard to the host and member countries.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>Below the six organs sit, in the words of author Linda Fasulo, "an amazing collection of entities and organizations, some of which are actually older than the UN itself and operate with almost complete independence from it".<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> These include specialised agencies, research and training institutions, programmes and funds, and other UN entities.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:United_Nations_Organs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:United Nations Organs (page does not exist)">Template:United Nations Organs</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="General_Assembly">General Assembly</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_828797_Mikhail_Gorbachev_addressing_UN_General_Assembly_session.jpg" title="File:RIAN archive 828797 Mikhail Gorbachev addressing UN General Assembly session.jpg">File:RIAN archive 828797 Mikhail Gorbachev addressing UN General Assembly session.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Soviet general secretary <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> addresses the UN General Assembly in December 1988.</div></div></div>
<p>The General Assembly is the main <a href="/wiki/Deliberative_assembly" title="Deliberative assembly">deliberative assembly</a> of the United Nations. Composed of all <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">United Nations member states</a>, the assembly meets in regular yearly sessions, but emergency sessions can also be called.<sup id="cite_ref-F131_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F131-48">[48]</a></sup> The assembly is led by a <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="President of the United Nations General Assembly">president</a>, elected from among the member states on a rotating regional basis, and 21&#160;vice-presidents.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> The first session was convened on 10&#160;January 1946 in the Methodist Central Hall Westminster in London and included representatives of 51&#160;nations.<sup id="cite_ref-unmilestones_6-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unmilestones-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>When the General Assembly votes on important questions, a two-thirds majority of those present and voting is required. Examples of important questions include recommendations on peace and security; election of members to organs; admission, suspension, and expulsion of members; and budgetary matters.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> All other questions are decided by majority vote. Each member country has one vote. Apart from approval of budgetary matters, resolutions are not binding on the members. The Assembly may make recommendations on any matters within the scope of the UN, except matters of peace and security that are under Security Council consideration.<sup id="cite_ref-F131_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F131-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>Draft resolutions can be forwarded to the General Assembly by eight committees:<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul>
<li>General Committee&#160;– a supervisory committee consisting of the assembly's president, vice-president, and committee heads
</li>
<li>Credentials Committee&#160;– responsible for determining the credentials of each member nation's UN representatives
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=General_Assembly_First_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="General Assembly First Committee (page does not exist)">First Committee (Disarmament and International Security)</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Economic_and_Financial_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economic and Financial Committee (page does not exist)">Second Committee (Economic and Financial)</a>
</li>
<li>Third Committee (Social, Humanitarian, and Cultural)
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Fourth_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Fourth Committee (page does not exist)">Fourth Committee (Special Political and Decolonization)</a>
</li>
<li>Fifth Committee (Administrative and Budgetary)
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_General_Assembly_Sixth_Committee_(Legal)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations General Assembly Sixth Committee (Legal) (page does not exist)">Sixth Committee (Legal)</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Security_Council">Security Council</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Powell-anthrax-vial.jpg" title="File:Powell-anthrax-vial.jpg">File:Powell-anthrax-vial.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/U.S._Secretary_of_State" title="U.S. Secretary of State" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Secretary of State</a> <a href="/wiki/Colin_Powell" title="Colin Powell">Colin Powell</a> demonstrates a vial with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Legitimacy_of_the_2003_invasion_of_Iraq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legitimacy of the 2003 invasion of Iraq (page does not exist)">alleged</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraq (page does not exist)">Iraqi</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chemical_weapon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chemical weapon (page does not exist)">chemical weapon</a> probes to the UN Security Council on <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_and_the_Iraq_War" title="United Nations Security Council and the Iraq War">Iraq war</a> hearings, 5 February 2003</div></div></div>
<p>The Security Council is charged with maintaining peace and security among countries. While other organs of the United Nations can only make "recommendations" to member states, the Security Council has the power to make binding decisions that member states have agreed to carry out, under the terms of Charter Article&#160;25.<sup id="cite_ref-Chapter.7CV_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chapter.7CV-52">[52]</a></sup> The decisions of the Council are known as <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_resolution" title="United Nations Security Council resolution">United Nations Security Council resolutions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Security Council is made up of 15&#160;member states, consisting of 5&#160;permanent members—China, France, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States—and 10&#160;non-permanent members. As of November 2013, these are Argentina (term ends 2014), Australia (2014), Azerbaijan (2013), Guatemala (2013), Luxembourg (2014), Morocco (2013), Pakistan (2013), Republic of Korea (2014), Rwanda (2014), and Togo (2013).<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> The five permanent members hold <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_veto_power" title="United Nations Security Council veto power">veto power</a> over UN resolutions, allowing a permanent member to block adoption of a resolution, though not debate. The ten temporary seats are held for two-year terms, with member states voted in by the General Assembly on a <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Regional_Groups&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Regional Groups (page does not exist)">regional basis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> The presidency of the Security Council rotates alphabetically each month.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Secretariat">Secretariat</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The UN Secretariat is headed by the <a href="/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations" title="Secretary-General of the United Nations">Secretary-General</a>, assisted by a staff of international civil servants worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> It provides studies, information, and facilities needed by United Nations bodies for their meetings. It also carries out tasks as directed by the Security Council, the General Assembly, the Economic and Social Council, and other UN bodies.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ban_Ki-moon_1-2.jpg" title="File:Ban Ki-moon 1-2.jpg">File:Ban Ki-moon 1-2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The current <a href="/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations" title="Secretary-General of the United Nations">Secretary-General</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon" title="Ban Ki-moon">Ban Ki-moon</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Secretary-General acts as the <i>de facto</i> spokesperson and leader of the UN. The position is defined in the UN Charter as the organisation's "chief administrative officer".<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> Article 99 of the charter states that the Secretary-General can bring to the Security Council's attention "any matter which in his opinion may threaten the maintenance of international peace and security", a phrase that Secretaries-General since <a href="/wiki/Trygve_Lie" title="Trygve Lie">Trygve Lie</a> have interpreted as giving the position broad scope for action on the world stage.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> The office has evolved into a dual role of an administrator of the UN organisation and a diplomat and mediator addressing disputes between member states and finding consensus to global issues.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Secretary-General is appointed by the General Assembly, after being recommended by the Security Council, where the permanent members have veto power.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> There are no specific criteria for the post, but over the years, it has become accepted that the post shall be held for one or two terms of five years, that the post shall be appointed on the basis of geographical rotation, and that the Secretary-General shall not originate from one of the five permanent Security Council member states.<sup id="cite_ref-una-usa-fact_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-una-usa-fact-63">[63]</a></sup> The current Secretary-General is <a href="/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon" title="Ban Ki-moon">Ban Ki-moon</a>, who replaced <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">Kofi Annan</a> in 2007 and was elected for a second term to conclude at the end of 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; text-align:left;">
<caption style="padding-top:1em;">Secretaries-General of the United Nations<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_Court_of_Justice">International Court of Justice</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The International Court of Justice (ICJ), located in The Hague, Netherlands, is the primary judicial organ of the UN. Established in 1945 by the UN Charter, the Court began work in 1946 as the successor to the <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Court_of_International_Justice" title="Permanent Court of International Justice">Permanent Court of International Justice</a>. The ICJ is composed of 15&#160;judges who serve 9-year terms and are appointed by the General Assembly; every sitting judge must be from a different nation.<sup id="cite_ref-F183_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F183-66">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is based in the <a href="/wiki/Peace_Palace" title="Peace Palace">Peace Palace</a> in The Hague, sharing the building with the <a href="/wiki/Hague_Academy_of_International_Law" title="Hague Academy of International Law">Hague Academy of International Law</a>, a private centre for the study of international law. The ICJ's primary purpose is to adjudicate disputes among states. The court has heard cases related to war crimes, illegal state interference, ethnic cleansing, and other issues.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> The ICJ can also be called upon by other UN organs to provide advisory opinions.<sup id="cite_ref-F183_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F183-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_and_Social_Council">Economic and Social Council</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) assists the General Assembly in promoting international economic and social co-operation and development. ECOSOC has 54&#160;members, which are elected by the General Assembly for a three-year term. The president is elected for a one-year term and chosen amongst the small or middle powers represented on ECOSOC. The council has one annual meeting in July, held in either New York or Geneva. Viewed as separate from the specialised bodies it coordinates, ECOSOC's functions include information gathering, advising member nations, and making recommendations.<sup id="cite_ref-F103_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F103-69">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Owing to its broad mandate of co-ordinating many agencies, ECOSOC has at times been criticised as unfocused or irrelevant.<sup id="cite_ref-F103_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F103-69">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>ECOSOC's subsidiary bodies include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Permanent_Forum_on_Indigenous_Issues&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues (page does not exist)">United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues</a>, which advises UN agencies on issues relating to <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">indigenous peoples</a>; the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Forum_on_Forests&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Forum on Forests (page does not exist)">United Nations Forum on Forests</a>, which coordinates and promotes sustainable forest management; the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Statistical_Commission" title="United Nations Statistical Commission">United Nations Statistical Commission</a>, which coordinates information-gathering efforts between agencies; and the <a href="/wiki/Commission_on_Sustainable_Development" title="Commission on Sustainable Development">Commission on Sustainable Development</a>, which coordinates efforts between UN agencies and NGOs working toward <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_development" title="Sustainable development">sustainable development</a>. ECOSOC may also grant consultative status to non-governmental organisations;<sup id="cite_ref-F103_69-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F103-69">[69]</a></sup> by 2004, more than 2,200 organisations had received this status.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Specialized_agencies">Specialized agencies</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The UN Charter stipulates that each primary organ of the UN can establish various specialised agencies to fulfill its duties.<sup id="cite_ref-CharterIX_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CharterIX-73">[73]</a></sup> Some of the best-known agencies are the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO (page does not exist)">UNESCO</a> (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization), the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">World Bank</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO). The UN performs most of its humanitarian work through these agencies. Examples include mass vaccination programmes (through WHO), the avoidance of famine and malnutrition (through the work of the WFP), and the protection of vulnerable and displaced people (for example, by <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">UNHCR</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%; text-align:left;">
<caption style="padding-top:1em;"><b>Organizations and specialized agencies of the United Nations</b>
</caption>
<tr>

</th></tr>
