</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 12 </td>
<td> UPU </td>
<td> <b><a href="/wiki/Universal_Postal_Union" title="Universal Postal Union">Universal Postal Union</a></b></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_CHE&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data CHE (page does not exist)">Template:Country data CHE</a> <a href="/wiki/Bern" title="Bern">Bern</a>, Switzerland </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_KEN&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data KEN (page does not exist)">Template:Country data KEN</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bishar_Abdirahman_Hussein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bishar Abdirahman Hussein (page does not exist)">Bishar Abdirahman Hussein</a> </td>
<td> 1947 (1874)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 13 </td>
<td> WBG </td>
<td> <b><a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">World Bank Group</a></b></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_USA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data USA (page does not exist)">Template:Country data USA</a> Washington, D.C., USA </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_USA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data USA (page does not exist)">Template:Country data USA</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jim_Yong_Kim&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jim Yong Kim (page does not exist)">Jim Yong Kim</a></td>
<td> 1945 (1944)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 14 </td>
<td> WFP </td>
<td> <b><a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a></b></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_ITA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data ITA (page does not exist)">Template:Country data ITA</a> Rome, Italy </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_USA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data USA (page does not exist)">Template:Country data USA</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ertharin_Cousin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ertharin Cousin (page does not exist)">Ertharin Cousin</a> </td>
<td> 1963
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 15 </td>
<td> WHO </td>
<td> <b><a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a></b></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_CHE&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data CHE (page does not exist)">Template:Country data CHE</a> <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a>, Switzerland </td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_HKG&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data HKG (page does not exist)">Template:Country data HKG</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Margaret_Chan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Margaret Chan (page does not exist)">Margaret Chan</a></td>
<td> 1948
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 16 </td>
<td> WIPO </td>
<td> <b><a href="/wiki/World_Intellectual_Property_Organization" title="World Intellectual Property Organization">World Intellectual Property Organization</a></b></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_CHE&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data CHE (page does not exist)">Template:Country data CHE</a> <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a>, Switzerland </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_AUS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data AUS (page does not exist)">Template:Country data AUS</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Francis_Gurry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Francis Gurry (page does not exist)">Francis Gurry</a> </td>
<td> 1974
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 17 </td>
<td> WMO </td>
<td> <b><a href="/wiki/World_Meteorological_Organization" title="World Meteorological Organization">World Meteorological Organization</a></b></td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_CHE&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data CHE (page does not exist)">Template:Country data CHE</a> <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a>, Switzerland </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_CAN&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data CAN (page does not exist)">Template:Country data CAN</a> David Grimes / <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_FRA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data FRA (page does not exist)">Template:Country data FRA</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michel_Jarraud&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michel Jarraud (page does not exist)">Michel Jarraud</a> </td>
<td> 1950 (1873)
</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Membership">Membership</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:UN_member_states_animation.gif" title="File:UN member states animation.gif">File:UN member states animation.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An animation showing the timeline of accession of UN member states, according to the UN. Antarctica has no government; political control of <a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">Western Sahara</a> is in dispute; and the territories administered by Taiwan and Kosovo are considered by the UN to be provinces of China and Serbia, respectively.</div></div></div>
<p>With the addition of <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Sudan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Sudan (page does not exist)">South Sudan</a> on 14 July 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> there are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:UNnum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:UNnum (page does not exist)">Template:UNnum</a> United Nations member states, including all <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">undisputed</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states" title="List of sovereign states">independent states</a> apart from <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-members_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-members-76">[76]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a>
The UN Charter outlines the rules for membership:
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<ol>
<li> Membership in the United Nations is open to all other peace-loving states that accept the obligations contained in the present Charter and, in the judgment of the Organization, are able and willing to carry out these obligations.
</li>
<li> The admission of any such state to membership in the United Nations will be effected by a decision of the General Assembly upon the recommendation of the Security Council. Chapter II, Article 4<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
</li>
</ol>
</blockquote>
<p>In addition, there are two <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_observers" title="United Nations General Assembly observers">non-member observer states of the United Nations General Assembly</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> (which holds sovereignty over Vatican City) and the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Palestine" title="State of Palestine">State of Palestine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands" title="Cook Islands">Cook Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Niue" title="Niue">Niue</a>, both <a href="/wiki/Associated_state" title="Associated state">states in free association</a> with New Zealand, are full members of several UN specialised agencies and have had their "full treaty-making capacity" recognised by the Secretariat.<sup id="cite_ref-art102_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art102-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Group_of_77">Group of 77</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The Group of 77 at the UN is a loose coalition of developing nations, designed to promote its members' collective economic interests and create an enhanced joint negotiating capacity in the United Nations. Seventy-seven nations founded the organisation, but by November 2013 the organisation had since expanded to 133 member countries.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> The group was founded on 15 June 1964 by the "Joint Declaration of the Seventy-Seven Countries" issued at the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_Trade_and_Development" title="United Nations Conference on Trade and Development">United Nations Conference on Trade and Development</a> (UNCTAD). The first major meeting was in <a href="/wiki/Algiers" title="Algiers">Algiers</a> in 1967, where the Charter of Algiers was adopted and the basis for permanent institutional structures was established.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Objectives">Objectives</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Peacekeeping_and_security">Peacekeeping and security</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bolivian_Army_2nd_Lt._Mauricio_Vidangos_stands_guard_at_the_entry_control_point_of_an_Observation_Point.jpg" title="File:Bolivian Army 2nd Lt. Mauricio Vidangos stands guard at the entry control point of an Observation Point.jpg">File:Bolivian Army 2nd Lt. Mauricio Vidangos stands guard at the entry control point of an Observation Point.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Bolivian "<a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_peacekeeping&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations peacekeeping (page does not exist)">Blue Helmet</a>" at an exercise in Chile</div></div></div>
<p>The UN, after approval by the Security Council, sends peacekeepers to regions where armed conflict has recently ceased or paused to enforce the terms of peace agreements and to discourage combatants from resuming hostilities. Since the UN does not maintain its own military, peacekeeping forces are voluntarily provided by member states. These soldiers are sometimes nicknamed "Blue Helmets" for their distinctive gear.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> The peacekeeping force as a whole received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2013, the UN had peacekeeping soldiers deployed on 15 missions. The largest was the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Organization_Stabilization_Mission_in_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo" title="United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo">United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo</a> (MONUSCO), which included 20,688 uniformed personnel. The smallest, <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Military_Observer_Group_in_India_and_Pakistan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan (page does not exist)">United Nations Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan</a> (UNMOGIP), included 42 uniformed personnel responsible for monitoring the ceasefire in <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir" title="Jammu and Kashmir">Jammu and Kashmir</a>. UN peacekeepers with the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Truce_Supervision_Organization" title="United Nations Truce Supervision Organization">United Nations Truce Supervision Organization</a> (UNTSO) have been stationed in the Middle East since 1948, the longest-running active peacekeeping mission.<sup id="cite_ref-UNPO_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNPO-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2005 RAND Corporation study found the UN to be successful in two out of three peacekeeping efforts. It compared UN nation-building efforts to those of the United States, and found that seven out of eight UN cases are at peace, as compared with four out of eight US cases at peace.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> Also in 2005, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_Security_Report_2005&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human Security Report 2005 (page does not exist)">Human Security Report</a> documented a decline in the number of wars, genocides, and human rights abuses since the end of the Cold War, and presented evidence, albeit circumstantial, that international activism—mostly spearheaded by the UN—has been the main cause of the decline in armed conflict in that period.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> Situations in which the UN has not only acted to keep the peace but also intervened include the Korean War (1950–53) and the authorization of intervention in Iraq after the Gulf War (1990–91).<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UN has also drawn criticism for perceived failures. In many cases, member states have shown reluctance to achieve or enforce Security Council resolutions. Disagreements in the Security Council about military action and intervention are seen as having failed to prevent the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1971_Bangladesh_genocide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1971 Bangladesh genocide (page does not exist)">1971 Bangladesh genocide</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Ball_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ball-89">[89]</a></sup> the 1970s <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Rouge_rule_of_Cambodia" title="Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia">Cambodian genocide</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> and the 1994 Rwandan Genocide.<sup id="cite_ref-Kennedy102_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kennedy102-91">[91]</a></sup> Similarly, UN inaction is blamed for failing to either prevent the 1995 <a href="/wiki/Srebrenica_massacre" title="Srebrenica massacre">Srebrenica massacre</a> or complete the 1992–93 peacekeeping operations during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Somali_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Somali Civil War (page does not exist)">Somali Civil War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> UN peacekeepers have also been accused of child rape, soliciting prostitutes, or sexual abuse during various peacekeeping missions in the Democratic Republic of the Congo,<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> Haiti,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> Liberia,<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Sudan and what is now South Sudan,<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> Burundi, and Ivory Coast.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> Scientists cited UN peacekeepers from Nepal as the likely source of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010%E2%80%9313_Haiti_cholera_outbreak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010–13 Haiti cholera outbreak (page does not exist)">2010–13 Haiti cholera outbreak</a>, which killed more than 8,000 Haitians following the 2010 Haiti earthquake.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to peacekeeping, the UN is also active in encouraging <a href="/wiki/Disarmament" title="Disarmament">disarmament</a>. Regulation of armaments was included in the writing of the UN Charter in 1945 and was envisioned as a way of limiting the use of human and economic resources for their creation.<sup id="cite_ref-Chapter.7CV_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chapter.7CV-52">[52]</a></sup> The advent of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapons</a> came only weeks after the signing of the charter, resulting in the first <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_resolution" title="United Nations General Assembly resolution">resolution</a> of the first General Assembly meeting calling for specific proposals for "the elimination from national armaments of atomic weapons and of all other major weapons adaptable to mass destruction".<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> The UN has been involved with arms-limitation treaties such as the <a href="/wiki/Outer_Space_Treaty" title="Outer Space Treaty">Outer Space Treaty</a> (1967), the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons">Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons</a> (1968), the <a href="/wiki/Seabed_Arms_Control_Treaty" title="Seabed Arms Control Treaty">Seabed Arms Control Treaty</a> (1971), the <a href="/wiki/Biological_Weapons_Convention" title="Biological Weapons Convention">Biological Weapons Convention</a> (1972), the <a href="/wiki/Chemical_Weapons_Convention" title="Chemical Weapons Convention">Chemical Weapons Convention</a> (1992), and the <a href="/wiki/Ottawa_Treaty" title="Ottawa Treaty">Ottawa Treaty</a> (1997), which prohibits landmines.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Three UN bodies oversee arms proliferation issues: the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_the_Prohibition_of_Chemical_Weapons" title="Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons">Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Comprehensive_Nuclear-Test-Ban_Treaty_Organization_Preparatory_Commission&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization Preparatory Commission (page does not exist)">Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization Preparatory Commission</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3>
<p>One of the UN's primary purposes is "promoting and encouraging respect for human rights and for fundamental freedoms for all without distinction as to race, sex, language, or religion", and member states pledge to undertake "joint and separate action" to protect these rights.<sup id="cite_ref-CharterIX_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CharterIX-73">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Charter1_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charter1-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EleanorRooseveltHumanRights.png" title="File:EleanorRooseveltHumanRights.png">File:EleanorRooseveltHumanRights.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Eleanor_Roosevelt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eleanor Roosevelt (page does not exist)">Eleanor Roosevelt</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights" title="Universal Declaration of Human Rights">Universal Declaration of Human Rights</a> in 1949</div></div></div>
<p>In 1948, the General Assembly adopted a <a href="/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights" title="Universal Declaration of Human Rights">Universal Declaration of Human Rights</a>, drafted by a committee headed by Franklin D. Roosevelt's widow <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eleanor_Roosevelt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eleanor Roosevelt (page does not exist)">Eleanor</a> and including French lawyer <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Cassin" title="René Cassin">René Cassin</a>. The document proclaims basic civil, political, and economic rights common to all human beings, though its effectiveness toward achieving these ends has been disputed since the its drafting.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> The Declaration serves as a "common standard of achievement for all peoples and all nations" rather than a legally binding document, but it has become the basis of two binding treaties, the 1966 <a href="/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Civil_and_Political_Rights" title="International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights">International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights</a> and <a href="/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Economic,_Social_and_Cultural_Rights" title="International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights">International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> In practice, the UN is unable to take significant action against human rights abuses without a Security Council resolution, though it does substantial work in investigating and reporting abuses.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1979, the General Assembly adopted the <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_the_Elimination_of_All_Forms_of_Discrimination_against_Women" title="Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women">Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women</a>, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_the_Rights_of_the_Child" title="Convention on the Rights of the Child">Convention on the Rights of the Child</a> in 1989.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> With the end of the Cold War, the push for human rights action took on new impetus.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Commission_on_Human_Rights" title="United Nations Commission on Human Rights">United Nations Commission on Human Rights</a> was formed in 1993 to oversee human rights issues for the UN, following the recommendation of that year's <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Conference_on_Human_Rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Conference on Human Rights (page does not exist)">World Conference on Human Rights</a>. French scholar Jacques Fomerand describes this organisation's mandate as "broad and vague", with only "meager" resources to carry it out.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> In 2006, it was replaced by a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Council" title="United Nations Human Rights Council">Human Rights Council</a> consisting of 47 nations.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> Also in 2006, the General Assembly passed a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Declaration_on_the_Rights_of_Indigenous_Peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (page does not exist)">Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> and in 2011, it passed its first resolution recognizing the rights of <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> people.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other UN bodies responsible for <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights" title="Women's rights">women's rights</a> issues include <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Commission_on_the_Status_of_Women&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Commission on the Status of Women (page does not exist)">United Nations Commission on the Status of Women</a>, a commission of ECOSOC founded in 1946; the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Fund_for_Women" title="United Nations Development Fund for Women">United Nations Development Fund for Women</a>, created in 1976; and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_International_Research_and_Training_Institute_for_the_Advancement_of_Women&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations International Research and Training Institute for the Advancement of Women (page does not exist)">United Nations International Research and Training Institute for the Advancement of Women</a>, founded in 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> The United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues, one of three bodies with a mandate to oversee issues related to indigenous peoples, held its first session in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_development_and_humanitarian_assistance">Economic development and humanitarian assistance</span></h3>
<table style="background:#f3f9ff; padding-left:7px; padding-bottom:7px; float:right; border:1px dashed #aaa; margin-left:1em; margin-bottom:1em;">

<tr>
<td colspan="2">
<p><b>Millennium Development Goals</b>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="vertical-align:top; font-size:100%;">
<ol>
<li> eradicate extreme poverty and hunger;
</li>
<li> achieve universal primary education;
</li>
<li> promote gender equality and empower women;
</li>
<li> reduce child mortality;
</li>
<li> improve maternal health;
</li>
<li> combat HIV/AIDS, malaria, and other diseases;
</li>
<li> ensure environmental sustainability; and
</li>
<li> develop a global partnership for development.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>
</li>
</ol>
</td></tr></table>
<p>Another primary purpose of the UN is "to achieve international co-operation in solving international problems of an economic, social, cultural, or humanitarian character".<sup id="cite_ref-Charter1_102-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charter1-102">[102]</a></sup> Numerous bodies have been created to work toward this goal, primarily under the authority of the General Assembly and ECOSOC.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> In 2000, the then-192 United Nations member states agreed to achieve eight <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Development_Goals" title="Millennium Development Goals">Millennium Development Goals</a> by 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme" title="United Nations Development Programme">UN Development Programme</a> (UNDP), an organisation for grant-based technical assistance founded in 1945, is one of the leading bodies in the field of <a href="/wiki/International_development" title="International development">international development</a>. The organisation also publishes the UN <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, a comparative measure <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by Human Development Index (page does not exist)">ranking countries</a> by poverty, literacy, education, life expectancy, and other factors.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a> (FAO), also founded in 1945, promotes agricultural development and food security.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNICEF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNICEF (page does not exist)">UNICEF</a> (the United Nations Children's Fund) was created in 1946 to aid European children after World War II and expanded its mission to provides aid around the world and to uphold the Convention on the Rights of the Child.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">World Bank Group</a> and <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF) are independent, specialised agencies and observers within the UN framework, according to a 1947 agreement. They were initially formed separately from the UN through the <a href="/wiki/Bretton_Woods_system" title="Bretton Woods system">Bretton Woods Agreement</a> in 1944.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> The World Bank provides loans for international development, while the IMF promotes international economic cooperation and gives emergency loans to indebted countries.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO), which focuses on international health issues and disease eradication, is another of the UN's largest agencies. In 1980, the agency announced that the eradication of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Smallpox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smallpox (page does not exist)">smallpox</a> had been completed. In subsequent decades, WHO largely eradicated <a href="/wiki/Polio" title="Polio" class="mw-redirect">polio</a>, <a href="/wiki/River_blindness" title="River blindness" class="mw-redirect">river blindness</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Leprosy" title="Leprosy">leprosy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Joint_United_Nations_Programme_on_HIV/AIDS" title="Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS">Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS</a> (UNAIDS), begun in 1996, coordinates the organisation's response to the AIDS epidemic.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=UN_Population_Fund&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UN Population Fund (page does not exist)">UN Population Fund</a>, which also dedicates part of its resources to combating HIV, is the world's largest source of funding for <a href="/wiki/Reproductive_health" title="Reproductive health">reproductive health</a> and <a href="/wiki/Family_planning" title="Family planning">family planning</a> services.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup>
</p><p>Along with the <a href="/wiki/International_Red_Cross_and_Red_Crescent_Movement" title="International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement">International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement</a>, the UN often takes a leading role in coordinating emergency relief.<sup id="cite_ref-Fasulo183_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fasulo183-127">[127]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a> (WFP), created in 1961, provides food aid in response to famine, natural disasters, and armed conflict. The organisation reports that it feeds an average of 90 million people in 80 nations each year.<sup id="cite_ref-Fasulo183_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fasulo183-127">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees" class="mw-redirect">Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees</a> (UNHCR), established in 1950, works to protect the rights of refugees, asylum seekers, and stateless people.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> UNHCR and WFP programmes are funded by voluntary contributions from governments, corporations, and individuals, though the UNHCR's administrative costs are paid for by the UN's primary budget.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other">Other</span></h3>
<p>Since the UN's creation, over 80 colonies have attained independence. The General Assembly adopted the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Declaration_on_the_Granting_of_Independence_to_Colonial_Countries_and_Peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples (page does not exist)">Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples</a> in 1960 with no votes against but abstentions from all major colonial powers. The UN works toward decolonization through groups including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Special_Committee_on_Decolonization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Special Committee on Decolonization (page does not exist)">UN Committee on Decolonization</a>, created in 1962.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> As of 2013, the committee lists seventeen remaining "Non-Self-Governing Territories", the largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">Western Sahara</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beginning with the formation of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UN_Environmental_Programme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UN Environmental Programme (page does not exist)">UN Environmental Programme</a> (UNEP) in 1972, the UN has made environmental issues a prominent part of its agenda. A lack of success in the first two decades of UN work in this area led to the 1992 <a href="/wiki/Earth_Summit" title="Earth Summit">Earth Summit</a> in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, which sought to give new impetus to these efforts.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup>  In 1988, the UNEP and the <a href="/wiki/World_Meteorological_Organization" title="World Meteorological Organization">World Meteorological Organization</a> (WMO), another UN organisation, established the <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmental_Panel_on_Climate_Change" title="Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change">Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change</a>, which assesses and reports on research on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming (page does not exist)">global warming</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The UN-sponsored <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol</a>, signed in 1997, set legally-binding emissions reduction targets for ratifying states.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UN also declares and coordinates <a href="/wiki/International_observance" title="International observance">international observances</a>, periods of time to observe issues of international interest or concern. Examples include <a href="/wiki/World_Tuberculosis_Day" title="World Tuberculosis Day">World Tuberculosis Day</a>, <a href="/wiki/Earth_Day" title="Earth Day">Earth Day</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Year_of_Deserts_and_Desertification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Year of Deserts and Desertification (page does not exist)">International Year of Deserts and Desertification</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Funding">Funding</span></h2>
<table class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; white-space:nowrap; text-align:left; float:right; margin:10px;">
<caption>Top 17 contributors to the UN budget, 2013<sup id="cite_ref-unbudget_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unbudget-137">[137]</a></sup>
</caption>
<tr>
<th style="width:130px;"> <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">Member state</a>
</th>
<th> Contribution<br /><small>(<a href="/wiki/Percentage" title="Percentage">%</a> of UN budget)</small>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data United States (page does not exist)">Template:Country data United States</a></b> </td>
<td> 22.000%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Japan (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Japan</a></b> </td>
<td> 10.833%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Germany (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Germany</a></b> </td>
<td> 7.141%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data France (page does not exist)">Template:Country data France</a></b> </td>
<td> 5.593%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Template:Country data United Kingdom</a></b> </td>
<td> 5.179%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data China (page does not exist)">Template:Country data China</a></b> </td>
<td> 5.148%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Italy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Italy (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Italy</a></b> </td>
<td> 4.448%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Canada (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Canada</a></b> </td>
<td> 2.984%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Spain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Spain (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Spain</a></b> </td>
<td> 2.973%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Brazil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Brazil (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Brazil</a></b> </td>
<td> 2.934%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Russia (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Russia</a></b> </td>
<td> 2.438%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Australia (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Australia</a></b> </td>
<td> 2.074%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_South_Korea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data South Korea (page does not exist)">Template:Country data South Korea</a></b> </td>
<td> 1.994%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Mexico (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Mexico</a></b> </td>
<td> 1.842%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Netherlands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Netherlands (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Netherlands</a></b> </td>
<td> 1.654%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Turkey (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Turkey</a></b> </td>
<td> 1.328%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Switzerland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Switzerland (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Switzerland</a></b> </td>
<td> 1.047%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <b>Other member states</b> </td>
<td> 18.390%
</td></tr></table>
<p>The UN is financed from assessed and voluntary contributions from member states. The General Assembly approves the regular budget and determines the assessment for each member. This is broadly based on the relative capacity of each country to pay, as measured by their <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">gross national income</a> (GNI), with adjustments for external debt and low per capita income.<sup id="cite_ref-fifth-2006_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fifth-2006-138">[138]</a></sup> The two-year budget for 2012–13 totaled $5.512 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Assembly has established the principle that the UN should not be overly dependent on any one member to finance its operations. Thus, there is a "ceiling" rate, setting the maximum amount that any member can be assessed for the regular budget. In December 2000, the Assembly revised the scale of assessments in response to US government urging. As part of that revision, the regular budget ceiling was reduced from 25% to 22%.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> For the <a href="/wiki/Least_developed_country" title="Least developed country">least developed countries</a> (LDCs), a ceiling rate of 0.01% is applied.<sup id="cite_ref-fifth-2006_138-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fifth-2006-138">[138]</a></sup> In addition to the ceiling rates, the minimum amount assessed to any member nation (or "floor" rate) is set at 0.001% of the UN budget.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>A large share of UN expenditures addresses the core UN mission of peace and security, and this budget is assessed separately from the main organisational budget.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> The peacekeeping budget for the 2013–14 fiscal year was $7.54&#160;billion, supporting 82,318 troops deployed in 15 missions around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-UNPO_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNPO-85">[85]</a></sup> UN peace operations are funded by assessments, using a formula derived from the regular funding scale that includes a weighted surcharge for the five permanent Security Council members, who must approve all peacekeeping operations. This surcharge serves to offset discounted peacekeeping assessment rates for less developed countries. In 2013, the top 10 providers of assessed financial contributions to United Nations peacekeeping operations were the US (28.38%), Japan (10.83%), France (7.22%), Germany (7.14%), the United Kingdom (6.68%), China (6.64%), Italy (4.45%), Russian Federation (3.15%), Canada (2.98%), and Spain (2.97%).<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>Special UN programmes not included in the regular budget, such as UNICEF and the World Food Programme, are financed by voluntary contributions from member governments, corporations, and private individuals.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Evaluations.2C_awards.2C_and_criticism">Evaluations, awards, and criticism</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>A number of agencies and individuals associated with the UN have won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Peace_Prize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Peace Prize (page does not exist)">Nobel Peace Prize</a> in recognition of their work. Secretaries-General Dag Hammarskjöld and Kofi Annan were both awarded the prize (in 1961 and 2001, respectively), as were UN negotiator Ralph Bunche (1950), Universal Declaration of Human Rights contributor René Cassin (1968), and US Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Cordell_Hull" title="Cordell Hull">Cordell Hull</a> (1945), the latter for his role in the organisation's founding. Canadian <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_External_Affairs" title="Secretary of State for External Affairs" class="mw-redirect">Secretary of State for External Affairs</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lester_B._Pearson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lester B. Pearson (page does not exist)">Lester B. Pearson</a> was awarded the prize in 1957 for his role in organizing the UN's first peacekeeping force to resolve the Suez Crisis. UNICEF won the prize in 1965, the <a href="/wiki/International_Labour_Organization" title="International Labour Organization">International Labour Organization</a> in 1969, the UN Peace-Keeping Forces in 1988, the International Atomic Energy Agency (which reports to the UN) in 2005, and the UN-supported <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organization_for_the_Prohibition_of_Chemical_Weapons&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (page does not exist)">Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons</a> in 2013. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees was awarded in 1954 and 1981, becoming one of only two recipients to win the prize twice. The UN as a whole was awarded the prize in 2001, sharing it with Annan.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since its founding, there have been many calls for <a href="/wiki/Reform_of_the_United_Nations" title="Reform of the United Nations">reform of the United Nations</a> but little consensus on how to do so. Some want the UN to play a greater or more effective role in world affairs, while others want its role reduced to humanitarian work. There have also been numerous calls for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reform_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reform of the United Nations Security Council (page does not exist)">UN Security Council's membership to be increased</a>, for different ways of electing the UN's Secretary-General, and for a <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Parliamentary_Assembly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Parliamentary Assembly (page does not exist)">United Nations Parliamentary Assembly</a>. Scholar Jacques Fomerand states the most enduring divide in views of the UN is "the North-South split" between <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_divide" title="North–South divide">richer Northern nations and developing Southern nations</a>. Southern nations tend to favour a more empowered UN with a stronger General Assembly, allowing them a greater voice in world affairs, while Northern nations prefer an economically <a href="/wiki/Laissez-faire" title="Laissez-faire">laissez-faire</a> UN that focuses on transnational threats such as terrorism.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the Second World War, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=French_Committee_of_National_Liberation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="French Committee of National Liberation (page does not exist)">French Committee of National Liberation</a> was late to be recognised by the US as the government of France, and so the country was initially excluded from the conferences that aimed at creating the new organisation. Future French president <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a> criticised the UN, famously calling it a <i>machin</i> ("contraption"), and was not convinced that a global security alliance would help maintain world peace, preferring direct defence treaties between countries.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> Throughout the Cold War, both the US and USSR repeatedly accused the UN of favouring the other. The USSR effectively forced the resignation of Secretary-General Trygve Lie in 1953 through its refusal to deal with him, while in the 1950s and '60s, a popular US bumper sticker read, "You can't spell communism without U.N.".<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> In a sometimes-misquoted statement, US President <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_W._Bush&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George W. Bush (page does not exist)">George W. Bush</a> stated in February 2003 (referring to UN uncertainty toward Iraqi provocations under the Saddam Hussein regime) that "free nations will not allow the United Nations to fade into history as an ineffective, irrelevant debating society."<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> In contrast, French President <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Hollande" title="François Hollande">François Hollande</a> stated in 2012 that "France trusts the United Nations. She knows that no state, no matter how powerful, can solve urgent problems, fight for development and bring an end to all crises... France wants the UN to be the centre of global governance."<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> Critics such as Israeli diplomat <a href="/wiki/Dore_Gold" title="Dore Gold">Dore Gold</a>, British scholar <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_S._Wistrich&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert S. Wistrich (page does not exist)">Robert S. Wistrich</a>, American legal scholar <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alan_Dershowitz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alan Dershowitz (page does not exist)">Alan Dershowitz</a>, Australian politician <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mark_Dreyfus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mark Dreyfus (page does not exist)">Mark Dreyfus</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anti-Defamation_League&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anti-Defamation League (page does not exist)">Anti-Defamation League</a> consider UN attention to Israel's treatment of Palestinians to be excessive.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>Critics have also accused the UN of bureaucratic inefficiency, waste, and corruption. In 1976 the General Assembly established the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joint_Inspection_Unit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joint Inspection Unit (page does not exist)">Joint Inspection Unit</a> to seek out inefficiencies within the UN system. During the 1990s, the US withheld dues citing inefficiency and only started repayment on the condition that a major reforms initiative was introduced. In 1994, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Office_of_Internal_Oversight_Services" title="United Nations Office of Internal Oversight Services">Office of Internal Oversight Services</a> (OIOS) was established by the General Assembly to serve as an efficiency watchdog.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> In 2004, the UN faced accusations that its recently ended <a href="/wiki/Oil-for-Food_Programme" title="Oil-for-Food Programme">Oil-for-Food Programme</a>&#8212;in which Iraq had been allowed to trade oil for basic needs to relieve the pressure of sanctions&#8212;had suffered from widespread corruption, including billions of dollars of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kickback_(bribery)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kickback (bribery) (page does not exist)">kickbacks</a>. An independent inquiry created by the UN found that numerous organization officials had been involved, as well as raising "significant" questions about the role of <a href="/wiki/Kojo_Annan" title="Kojo Annan">Kojo Annan</a>, son of Secretary-General Kofi Annan.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>In evaluating the UN as a whole, Jacques Fomerand writes that the "accomplishments of the United Nations in the last 60 years are impressive in their own terms. Progress in human development during the 20th century has been dramatic and the UN and its agencies have certainly helped the world become a more hospitable and livable place for millions."<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> Evaluating the first 50 years of the UN's history, author Stanley Meisler writes that "the United Nations never fulfilled the hopes of its founders, but it accomplished a great deal nevertheless", citing its role in decolonization and its many successful peacekeeping efforts.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> British historian <a href="/wiki/Paul_Kennedy" title="Paul Kennedy">Paul Kennedy</a> states that while the organisation has suffered some major setbacks, "when all its aspects are considered, the UN has brought great benefits to our generation and ... will bring benefits to our children's and grandchildren's generations as well."<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

</li>

</li>
</ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Notelist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Notelist (page does not exist)">Template:Notelist</a>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<dl>
<dt>Citations
</dt>
</dl>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<dl>
<dt>Bibliography
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>Coulon, Jocelyn. <i>Soldiers of Diplomacy: The United Nations, Peacekeeping, and the New World Order</i>. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 1998.
</li>
<li>Fasulo, Linda. <i>An Insider's Guide to the UN</i>. New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 2004. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780300141979" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0300141979</a>
</li>
<li>Fomerand, Jacques. <i>The A to Z of the United Nations</i>. Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 2009.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Dore_Gold" title="Dore Gold">Gold, Dore</a>. <i>Tower of Babble: How the United Nations Has Fueled Global Chaos</i>. New York: Three Rivers Press, 2004.
</li>
<li> Grant, Thomas D. <i>Admission to the United Nations: Charter Article 4 and the Rise of Universal Organization</i>. Leiden: Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, 2009.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Paul_Kennedy" title="Paul Kennedy">Kennedy, Paul</a>. <i>The Parliament of Man: The Past, Present, and Future of the United Nations</i>. New York: Random House, 2006.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/William_Manchester" title="William Manchester">Manchester, William</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paul_Reid_(writer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paul Reid (writer) (page does not exist)">Reid, Paul</a>. <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Last_Lion:_Winston_Spencer_Churchill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Last Lion: Winston Spencer Churchill (page does not exist)">The Last Lion: Defender of the Realm</a></i> vol. 3. New York: Little Brown and Company, 2012.
</li>
<li> Meisler, Stanley. <i>United Nations: The First Fifty Years</i>. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press, 1995.
</li>
<li> Mires, Charlene. <i>Capital of the World: The Race to Host the United Nations</i>. New York: New York University Press, 2013.
</li>
<li> Weiss, Thomas G. and Sam Daws, eds. <i>The Oxford Handbook on the United Nations</i>. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2007.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_S._Wistrich&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert S. Wistrich (page does not exist)">Wistrich, Robert S.</a> <i>A Lethal Obsession: Anti-Semitism from Antiquity to the Global Jihad</i>. New York: Random House, 2010.
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/index.php?cPath=1037_3130_3369">United Nations Intellectual History Project Book Series</a>. Indiana University Press.
</li>
<li>Lowe, Vaughan; Adams Roberts; Jennifer Welsh; and Dominik Zaum, eds. (2010). <i>The United Nations Security Council and War: The Evolution of Thought and Practice since 1945</i>. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
</li>
<li>Robert, Adam and Benedict Kingsbury, eds. (1993). <i>United Nations, Divided World: The UN's Roles in International Relations</i>. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
</li>
<li>Schlesinger, Stephen (2003). <i>Act of Creation: The Founding of the United Nations</i>. Boulder, CO: Westview Press.
</li>
</ul>

</li>

</li>

<dl>
<dt>Other
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>

</li>

</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.globalpolicy.org/">Website</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Global_Policy_Forum" title="Global Policy Forum">Global Policy Forum</a>, an independent think tank on the UN
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.unwatch.org/">UN Watch</a> – NGO monitoring UN activities
</li>
</ul>
